Their problem is this :—When a man dies, what becomes oi his property, and who, ir any one, becomes answerable sor his liabilities?

According to the Roman view, as soon as a man died his proprietary relations assumed a separate, independent, and collective existence: his universitas iuris became specifically an hereditas, belonging, in many cases, as yet to no one, and as it were perpetuating the existence of the deceased: ‘res hereditariae, antequam aliquis heres existat, nullius in bonis sunt' Dig. 1. 8. 1.pr. 1t became, in sacta juristic person, as capable, in many respects, ol acquiring rights and incurring liabilities as a natural person: ‘hereditas non heredis personam sed defuncti sustinetur multis argumentis iuris civilis probandum est' Dig.41. 1. 33. 2, ‘mortuo reo promittendi et ante aditam hereditatem fideiussor accipi potest, quia hereditas personae vice fungitur, sicuti municipium et decuria et societas¹ Dig. 46. r. 22.

There is no precise resemblance between the Roman heres 3ῃά the English heir. The latter is the person who succeeds to such real property oi a deceased person as he has not disposed ol by will : the tormer was the person who succeeded to the universitas iuris osa deceased, whether under a will or an intestacy: and succeeding as he did to the universitas iuris, there was necessarily no more distinction between realty and per· sonalty than between rights and liabilities.

Until the hereditas had vested in an heir or heirs, and so lost its inde· pendent existence, it remained a persona under the name os hereditas iacens. In the heir or heirs, taken collectively, it can vest only as a whole: until it has so vested, the rights and liabilities of which it consists are inseparable. Where there is no will, this is not difficult to realise even to a mind habituated to the English distinction between realty and personalty: hut even where there was a will, the testator could not begin by saying ‘1 bequeath so and so to A :' he must first give it to the heir or heirs, as a part oi the aggregate universitas, and charge them to give it to the intended legatee. Universality os succession is thus the prime characteristic oi the Roman law os inheritance: ‘nihil est aliud hereditas, ¹quam successio in universum ius, quod defunctus hahuit ' Dig. 50. 16. 24.
